subject: polity
title: Central Government Funds (Art 266-267)
description: Comparison of Consolidated Fund, Public Account, and Contingency Fund of India with their constitutional provisions and usage

rows.constitutionalProvision:
• **Art 266(1)**: All revenues received, loans raised, money received in repayment of loans → CFI
• **Art 266(3)**: No money can be appropriated from CFI except as per Appropriation law
• Most important fund - **Public account of Government**
rows.natureComposition:
**Receipts:**
• All **tax revenues** (Income Tax, GST, Customs, Excise)
• All **non-tax revenues** (Interest, Dividends, Fees, Fines)
• All **loans raised** by Government
• **Repayment of loans** given by Govt
**Expenditure:**
• All **government expenditure** (salaries, schemes, subsidies, debt repayment)
rows.purposeUsage:
**Purpose:**
• **Main account** for Government's financial operations
• Funds all government activities (defense, education, health, infrastructure)
• Services government debt (interest payments)
**Usage:**
• Charged expenditure paid directly (President, Judges, CAG, Debt)
• Voted expenditure paid after Parliament's approval (Demands for Grants)
rows.withdrawalControl:
**Withdrawal:**
• **Parliamentary authorization** mandatory (Art 266(3))
• **Appropriation Act** needed for withdrawal
• No money can be withdrawn without Parliament's vote
**Control:**
• Parliament has full control
• Lok Sabha votes on expenditure
• CAG audits all expenditure

rows.constitutionalProvision:
• **Art 266(2)**: Money received by Govt in which Govt acts as **banker/trustee** (not owner)
• Government holds money **on behalf of others**
• Must be **returned/paid back** to rightful owners
rows.natureComposition:
**Receipts:**
• **Provident Funds** (GPF, CPF - employees' savings)
• **Small Savings** (Post Office deposits, NSC, PPF)
• **Reserve Funds** & **Deposits**
• **Other Liabilities** (pension funds, insurance)
**NOT included:**
• Government's own revenue (goes to CFI)
• Loans raised by govt (goes to CFI)
rows.purposeUsage:
**Purpose:**
• Government acts as **custodian** of public money
• These funds belong to **individuals/institutions** (not govt)
• Must be returned when due (retirement, maturity)
**Usage:**
• PF paid to employees on retirement
• Small savings returned with interest on maturity
• Pension paid from this account
rows.withdrawalControl:
**Withdrawal:**
• **NO parliamentary authorization** needed
• Money withdrawn to pay rightful claimants
• Executive has authority (Finance Ministry)
**Control:**
• Parliament does NOT vote on it
• CAG audits for proper utilization
• Finance Ministry manages

rows.constitutionalProvision:
• **Art 267(1)**: Parliament by law establishes **Contingency Fund** at disposal of **President**
• Currently **₹500 crore** (increased from ₹50 crore in 2005)
• **Imprest** (advance) account for emergencies
rows.natureComposition:
**Receipts:**
• **Parliamentary allocation** (initially ₹500 crore placed)
• Replenished after withdrawal (Parliament reimburses CFI)
**Nature:**
• **Emergency fund** at President's disposal
• **Advance** from this fund (later reimbursed from CFI)
• NOT Government's regular fund
rows.purposeUsage:
**Purpose:**
• Meet **urgent unforeseen expenditure** (disasters, calamities, emergencies)
• **Immediate action** possible (no time to wait for Parliament)
• **Temporary arrangement** till Parliament approves
**Usage:**
• Natural disasters (floods, earthquakes)
• Security emergencies
• Any urgent unforeseen need
**Recent Use:** COVID-19 pandemic (2020)
rows.withdrawalControl:
**Withdrawal:**
• President can authorize withdrawal (on PM/FM advice)
• **NO prior parliamentary approval** needed (emergency)
• After withdrawal, **Parliament must approve** & reimburse from CFI
**Control:**
• Executive has initial authority
• Parliament approves post-facto (Supplementary Grant)
• If Parliament rejects, money must be returned

notes: **Consolidated Fund = Government's Main Account**: All receipts (tax, non-tax, loans) → All expenditure (salaries, schemes, debt) → Parliamentary control (Appropriation Act)
**Public Account = Trustee Account**: Government holds money belonging to others (PF, small savings) → No parliamentary approval for withdrawal → Paid to rightful claimants
**Contingency Fund = Emergency Advance**: President's disposal for unforeseen urgent needs → No prior parliamentary approval → Later reimbursed from CFI after Parliament approves
**Key Distinction**: CFI = Govt's money (Parliamentary control); Public Account = Others' money (No Parliamentary control); Contingency Fund = Emergency advance (Post-facto Parliamentary control)
**State Funds**: States have similar 3 funds - Consolidated Fund of State (Art 266), Public Account of State (Art 266), Contingency Fund of State (Art 267(2)) under Governor's disposal
**CAG's Role (Art 149)**: CAG audits all 3 funds to ensure proper utilization & financial discipline
examTips: **Art 266(1) - CFI**: All govt receipts → All govt expenditure → Parliamentary Appropriation needed
**Art 266(2) - Public Account**: Govt as banker/trustee → Others' money (PF, small savings) → No Parliamentary approval for withdrawal
**Art 267 - Contingency Fund**: Emergency unforeseen expenditure → President's disposal → Post-facto Parliamentary approval
**Amount**: Contingency Fund = ₹500 crore (increased in 2005 from ₹50 crore)
**Parliamentary Control**: Maximum on CFI (Appropriation Act) → None on Public Account → Post-facto on Contingency Fund
**Ownership**: CFI (Govt's money) vs Public Account (Others' money held by Govt) vs Contingency Fund (Advance to Govt)
**Charged vs Voted from CFI**: Charged = No vote (President, Judges, CAG, Debt); Voted = Parliament votes (Demands for Grants)
importantCases: No landmark cases on Government Funds (financial constitutional provisions - Parliament's domain)
